     Hill 383 - Plava, Italy, June 20th 1915
     City of Violets - Gorizia, Italy, May 5h 1915
     First Rush - Podgorica, Italy, July 2nd 1915
     Isonzo Marsch - Tolmino, Italy, September 10th 1917
     Tolmino Bridgehead - Tolmino, Italy, September 12th 1917
     Cappuccio Wood - Mount San Michele, Italy, July 25th 1915
     Vrtojba - Vrtojba, Italy, November 4th 1916
     On To Monte Majur - Monte Majur, Italy, October 25th 1917

Name: ASL Comp: GWASL VII – Soldiers of the Sultan: Turkish WW1
Description:
The soldiers of the Ottoman Empire fought a variety of combatants during World War I. 
There were five main campaigns in the theatre: the Sinai and Palestine Campaign, the Mesopotamian Campaign, the Caucasus Campaign, the Persian Campaign, and most famously, the Gallipoli Campaign. 
The Ottomans joined the Central Powers, goaded by Germany, in its hope that Russian troops would be drained away from the fronts in Galicia and Poland. Scenarios in this module cover the Battle of Sarikamish, as well as the campaigns in Mesopotamia, Palestine, and OF COURSE … Gallippoli, one of the most disastrous campaigns of the Conflict. 
The Dardanelles campaign was fought on Turkish soil, as the ANZAC tried to create a passage through to the Black Sea. Gallipoli was the brainchild of Winston Churchill, and was a bitter failure. After massive hardship, ANZAC soldiers were withdrawn, having failed in most cases to even get off the beaches. Russia also invaded Turkish territory, in the north. Following the collapse of the Tsar’s government, the Turks swept north and entered Russian territory proper. By the Russian surrender in the Spring of 1918, the Turkish forces had taken Baku on the Caspian Sea.

Ownership ASL-RB, GWASL 1 and all preceding GWASL modules required to play.

Scenarios:

     The Bergmann Offensive - Caucasus Front, November 7th 1914
     Stand At Pine Ridge - Pine Ridge, Gallipoli Peninsula, April 25th 1915
     Plugge's Point - Z Beach, Geba Tabe, Gallipoli Peninsula, April 25th 1915
     Valley Of Death - Kereves Dere, Gallipoli Peninsula, June 21st 1915
     Forgotten Arabs - Gallipoli Peninsula, August 6th 1915
     Achi Baba Nulla - Cape Helles, Gallipoli Peninsula, June 4th 1915
     Fir Tree Spur - Cape Helles, Gallipoli Peninsula, May 8th 1915
     Australian Achilles - Gallipoli Peninsula, May 19th 1915

Name: Papertrail
Description: Players take turns rolling a dice and placing paper trails in the form of white counters on the spaces allocated on the game board. After all 48 tiles have been laid, players then take turns moving their pawns and collecting the counters either using forward movement or a combination of forward and backward movement, the sum of which must equal to the dice roll. When all players have completed the circuit, the game ends and the winner is the player with the most counters collected.

Name: Pirates Gold
Description: Players race through a track peppered with skull and crossbones spaces and treasure chest spaces. If a player lands on a skull and crossbones space, he/she takes a skull and crossbones card and go back X - Y spaces. If a player lands on a treasure chest space, he/she takes a treasure chest card and move forward X + Y spaces. The values of X and Y are given on each card.

Name: Land Rush: A Game of Of-Fence and De-Fence
Description:
Land Rush is played with Chess pieces on a Chess board, and for the most part the pieces have their normal Chess moves. (Pawn movement is slightly different.) However, other than kings pieces cannot capture, and the goal of the game is to build a connected chain of your pieces between the left and right edges of the board which fences off more than 32 squares.

The board starts empty. On a turn a player may create a piece or move an existing piece. Pieces are created on the owner's first rank and have point values: in order to create a piece there must be at least as many pieces in its file as its point value. (Pawns have a value of 0 so can be created at the start of the game.)

Name: Wizwords!: The Ultimate Crossword Game
Description:
In Wizwords! one or more players gradually build up a crossword grid as the game progresses. (The box says "1+" but six seems like a reasonable maximum number of players.)

On a turn a player draws a letter card and adds a word containing that letter to the grid, connected it to existing words as in Scrabble.

The grid starts with no black squares; after the first turn a player's turn starts by covering letters in previous words with black tiles to leave shorter words, or incomplete words which they complete on their turn.

Name: Zypher: The Scrambled Word Game
Description:
In Zypher players race to the end of a track by unscrambling anagrams in 30 seconds.

A player may choose to unscramble a five-letter anagram for a small benefit (e.g. advancing one's own piece or moving an opponent's back), or a six-letter anagram for a larger benefit (e.g. both moving your own piece forwards and another back).

Name: Suit Up!: Strings
Description:
Strings (one of two games in a article titled Suit Up!) is a no-luck card game.

Each player gets the 13 cards of a suit from a standard deck of cards, and takes turn playing one card at a time to a set of "strings" on the table. A "string" is a row of cards in ascending sequence with no gaps, e.g. a 4 must be followed by a 5, then a 6, etc.

A string can be started with any card except an ace, 10, or a court card; the latter are wild.

There is a limit of seven strings with three players and nine with four, which may make it impossible for a player to play later in the game, in which case they discard a card.

When all cards are gone players assess each string to see who wins it: 2-10 count their face values, aces count 11, and court cards count 5. The winner takes the string; if there is a tie the cards are split evenly. The player winning the most cards wins the game.

Several variants are provided.

Name: Check4
Description: Variant of Checkers with four players

Name: Suit Up!: Bidwise
Description:
Bidwise (one of two games in a article titled Suit Up!) is an auction game played using standard playing cards.

Each player gets the 13 cards in one suit. The property cards to be bid on are the ace-10 of the remaining suit/another deck, and are placed face-up on the table.

Each player shuffles their cards and each turn draws one and plays it. Cards are generally placed under property cards as bids of their face value; court cards can be bids worth five or can be used to remove an opposing bid card.

When all cards have been played the player bidding the most for each property wins it. The player with the greatest total value of properties wins the game.

A variant is given in which the bid cards can only be used on properties of matching value or one different.

Name: Valiant Wars: Champion's Expansion Pack 1
Description: Contains a cloth bag with 44 wooden token upgrades and 30 additional champion cards to add to the market with new abilities which help you push your luck or hinder your opponents in the quest to claim the Valiant Throne.

Name: Züge XXL 2 (fan expansion for Zooloretto)
Description:
Züge XXL 2 is an extension to connect the exit of Zooloretto Exotic with the Aquaretto adventure train. With this, after walking through the zoo, visitors will ride the adventure train through the Aquaretto water park.

Needed are:
Zooloretto
Zooloretto Exotic
The Aquaretto adventure train and if necessary
Aquaretto

—description from the designer (translated)

Es ist eine Erweiterung um den Ausgang von Zooloretto Exotic mit der Erlebnisbahn von Aquaretto zu verbinden. Damit fahren die Besucher nach dem Gang durch den Zoo mit der Erlebnisbahn durch den Aquaretto Wasser-Park.

Benötigt werden:
Zooloretto
Zooloretto Exotic
Die Erlebnisbahn von Aquaretto und ggf.
Aquaretto

—description from the designer

Name: Divide & Conquer: A Game of Galactic Isolation
Description:
Divide & Conquer is played on a small hexagonal grid with seven pieces for each player.

On a turn a player can move one of their ships to an adjacent empty space, as long as the ship is adjacent to at least one friendly ship.

Instead, a player can move an opposing ship which is adjacent to one of their ships (which is in turn adjacent to another friendly ship). They must move the opposing ship to a space where it isn't adjacent to any of its own ships, or to one of the black holes at the edges of the board, where it is lost forever.

The object of the game is to isolate or remove all the opposing ships.

If the players agree the game is stalemated a set of cards numbered 1-10 is used to remove a ship from each player.

Name: Hex-A-Gone
Description:
Hex-A-Gone is a solitaire puzzle game played on a hexagonal grid in a rhombus shape, five on a side.

There are 16 pieces: four each numbered 1-4. A move consists of jumping a piece over exactly the matching number of adjacent pieces. One of the jumped pieces is removed. The goal is to leave as few pieces as possible.

A starting position is given but others can be used.

Name: Robot Tricks
Description:
In Robot Tricks two-player teams each control a robot moving on a checkerboard, attempting to retrieve treasure chests.

The robots are controlled via card play, specifically by playing Spades. However, no bidding takes place and the number of tricks won is irrelevant. Instead, the winner of a trick chooses one of the four cards in it and moves their team's robot accordingly: the suit determines the direction and the rank determines how many spaces it moves, according to a table. Court cards allow the robot to be rotated.

However, if a trick contains an ace the winner chooses one of the other cards and moves the opposing team's robot instead.

When a robot moves to one of its treasures exactly it retrieves it. Opposing treasures and robots may be pushed.

The game can be set up with two treasures per team for a short game or four each for a long game.

Name: Khedu The Card Game
Description:
Khedu The Card Game is a fast paced 1-4 player fantasy card game where players compete against each other to build combat configurations with cards and dice. The objective is to earn as many points as you can before taking your last turn. Players spend energy to deploy heroes and spells -and earn points by building rewarding combat configurations.

The game ends when the last player has spent all their Energy tokens and completes their last turn. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins

-description from publisher

Name: Death In The Dark Continent: Lite – Wargames in 19th Century Africa
Description:
Death in the Dark Continent Lite

A complete set of rules for playing small battle wargames in 19th Century Africa.

This ‘cut down’ version of the full DitDC game provides all the rules you need; 
introducing new players to this exciting system and colourful period, and acting as a handy quick reference guide for existing players.

Published in April 2021 issue of Wargames Illustrated #400

—description from the publisher

Name: Mercato: Dominate the World's Market
Description:
Mercato: Dominate the World's Market is a dynamic game in which players acquire properties to gain control over key industries while navigating external events like wars, global warming, disruptive innovation, and pandemics.

Enjoy trading and attempting hostile takeovers on your quest for market dominance.

In Mercato: Dominate the World's Market, players engage in intense competition, strategically buying properties to concentrate ownership on global industries. The game's dynamic nature allows any player to build on their strategy, aiming to become the dominant player in the market and potentially bankrupt the rest of the players.

Name: Phoenix Command: Lock and Load Vietnam: 1965 - 1971 Supplement
Description:
Clearly one of the defining military conflicts of our time, the Vietnam War pitted the military might of the USA against the willpower of the Vietnamese Communists. Political and military leaders on both sides struggled to dictate the direction of a new kind of war, a guerilla war on an immense scale. The lessons learned in Vietnam have been applied to countless battlefields.

It was the soldier in the field who provided the lessons, by  learning them the hard way. This Scenario Pack allows players to re-create the Vietnam War as it was fought by the infantrymen of the forces involved: US Marines, US Army, South Vietnamese ARVN, ARVN Rangers, Regional Force/Popular Force, NVA Regulars, NVA Sappers and Viet Cong Guerillas.

Lock and Load includes seven scenarios drawn from the war: Jungle Patrol, Search and Destroy, Night Ambush, Street Fight, Fire Base defense, Rescue Operation, and Flank Security.

Each Scenario includes a pull page map designed for easy enlargement  to any s8ize. Equipment Options allow the scenarios to be customized with Punji Stakes, Trip Flares, Barbed Wire, Bangalore Torpedoes, Booby-Trapped Grenades, and more. Pre-Generated Troop data provides complete Combat and Weapon Data for 59 types of Combatants with 13 Weapons, allowing players to quickly set-up and play any scenario. Included are m1/M2 Carbine, M3 "Grease Gun", M1 Garand, BAR, M-14 and SKS Rifles, M-16 and AK-47 Assault Rifles, M-60 and RPD Machine Guns and RPG-2, RPG-7 and M-79 Grenade launchers.

The Revolution in Game Design Continues!
- from the back of the book

Name: Roll Crawl
Description:
The land is in peril! Two brave heroes, along with their trusty companion, must take on enemies of progressing difficulty, along with a challenging final boss, using only their wits and their abilities. Each player rolls 3 dice for their character, using push-your-luck mechanics to try to activate their most powerful abilities, or settle for whatever damage they can get, depending on their strategy.

Roll Crawl is a 1 to 2 player print and play game, with two heroes trying to activate their own abilities to reduce the health of their opponents to zero. They can forego activating their own abilities and combine their dice to active the abilities of their companion. But whatever you do, deal as much damage as you can. Your opponents are ready to hit back, with more dice than you. The more health they have, the more dice they roll, so players must be strategic about deciding when it is the right time to push their luck.

—description from the designer

Name: Chemline: Jouez avec les éléments !
Description:
Chemline is a card game consisting of 104 cards, corresponding to the first chemical elements.

Goal: create lines by placing cards in the order of, either the element's atomic number or, its year of discovery. 
In doing so, players become familiar with atomic elements and can discover different information about each element. 
The etymology of each name, the main uses of the elements, their molar masses and their electronegativity can all be found.

This is a free game (in French) available from their creators, the ENSCMu – Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Chimie de Mulhouse

Name: Great Tank Battle of Kursk
Description: Great Tank Battle of Kursk is a game of tactical combat between German tanks and Soviet tanks during the Battle of Kursk, published as a special supplement of MC Axis #37.

Name: Battle of Leyte Gulf
Description:
Solitaire game of the Battle of Leyte Gulf, published as a special supplement of MC Axis #46.
The player plays the role of Imperial Japanese Navy commander, organizes four fleets (Ozawa, Shima, Kurita and Nishimura) and intercepts U.S. Navy.

Name: Battle of Midway
Description:
Solitaire game of the Battle of Midway, published as a special supplement of MC Axis #49.
The player plays the role of Imperial Japanese Navy commander and runs after two hares — aims at bombing both Midway Island and U.S. aircraft carriers.
